keyTakeAways: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old from Ichikawa, Japan, made global headlines by scoring a game-winning 38-yard field goal in the NCAA college football season, becoming a symbol of perseverance and self-education.
Matsuzawa learned to kick football by watching YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle Seahawks kicker Jason Myers, and eventually imitated their techniques.
His journey was marked by personal adversity — failing an exam in Japan, losing motivation in youth, and working as a waiter and cutting his own hair to save money.
He received a scholarship to the University of Hawaii after being accepted by Hocking College in Ohio, where he improved his English and was exposed to American college football culture.
The article highlights Matsuzawa’s emotional journey and the support of his parents, who moved to a cheaper home to afford his education.
Matsuzawa is inspired by Japanese baseball star Shohei Ohtani and aspires to join the NFL, potentially becoming the first Japanese national to play in the league.
Coaches like Thomas Sheffield at the University of Hawaii praised Matsuzawa’s resilience, self-motivation, and emotional journey, calling it a powerful example of personal growth and determination.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old footballer from Ichikawa, Japan, gained global attention after scoring a game-winning 38-yard field goal in a college football game between the University of Hawaii and Stanford during the NCAA season. Having no formal coaching or English fluency, Matsuzawa learned to kick football by studying YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle Seahawks kicker Jason Myers. After failing an exam and losing motivation in Japan, he found renewed purpose by attending NFL games and later studying at Hocking College in Ohio, where he improved his English. His journey was supported by his parents, who made significant financial sacrifices to fund his education. He earned a scholarship to the University of Hawaii, where he was coached by Thomas Sheffield, who praised Matsuzawa’s resilience and self-motivation. Inspired by Japanese baseball star Shohei Ohtani, Matsuzawa now dreams of joining the NFL and becoming the first Japanese national to play professionally in the league, aiming to win a Super Bowl and play for a decade.
title: The NFL hopeful from Japan who learned to kick on YouTube
